qas.question: What thesis says a scientific hypothesis is not testable in isolation from its system of theories?
Which of Popper's works responds to critiques of naive falsificationism?
The planet Uranus' apparent failure to follow Newton's laws led to the discovery of which planet?
According to Popper, the scientific selection process favors which type of theory?
What thesis says it is possible to test a single hypothesis alone?
What can we conclusively say must be replaced?

plausible_answers.text: when the motion of Uranus was found not to match the predictions of Newton's laws

qas.question: When was the theory that there are eight planets in the solar system rejected?
What did Popper discuss in chapters 5 and 6 of The Logic of Scientific Discovery?
Why are Newton's laws not preferred over the other theory?

context: The <a0_0><b4_0>Quine-Duhem<b4_0/><a0_0/> thesis argues that it's impossible to test a single hypothesis on its own, since each one comes as part of an environment of theories. Thus we can only say that the whole package of relevant theories has been collectively falsified, but cannot conclusively say which <b5_0>element of the package<b5_0/> must be replaced. An example of this is given by the discovery of the planet <a2_0>Neptune<a2_0/>: <b6_0>when the motion of Uranus was found not to match the predictions of Newton's laws<b6_0/>, the theory "There are seven planets in the solar system" was rejected, and not Newton's laws themselves. Popper discussed this <b7_0>critique of naïve falsificationism<b7_0/> in Chapters 3 and 4 of <a1_0>The Logic of Scientific Discovery<a1_0/>. For Popper, theories are accepted or rejected via a sort of selection process. Theories that say more about the way things appear are to be preferred over those that do not; the <a3_0>more generally applicable<a3_0/> a theory is, the greater its value. Thus Newton's laws, with their <b8_0>wide general application<b8_0/>, are to be preferred over the much more specific "the solar system has seven planets".[dubious – discuss]
